This postcard dates from the early part of the 20th Century and the following is the description on the rear of the card. Since Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee the clock tower has been known as the "Elizabeth Tower." THE GREAT WESTMINSTER CLOCK, striking on “BIG BEN" in the Clock Tower of the Houses of Parliament, was made and fixed in the Clock Tower in the year 1858, by F. DENT, the predecessor of E. DENT & Co., Ltd., 28 COCKSPUR STREET and 4 ROYAL EXCHANGE, LONDON, and has been in their charge ever since. It is the Largest Striking, most accurate and powerful, Public Clock in the World. The first blow on “Big Ben” at each hour denotes correct time. The Form DIALS are each 23 feet in diameter, the centres being 180 feet from the ground and are illuminated by high- power electric lamps at night. The figures are 2 feet long and the minute spaces 1 foot square. The MINUTE HANDS are 14 feet long and weigh about 2 cwt. each; they are made of copper, and travel a distance equal to 100 miles each year. The HOUR‘ HANDS are 9 feet long and weigh about 6 cwt. each; they are made of gunmetal. The PENDULUM is 13 feet long, beating 2 seconds; the bob of the Pendulum weighs 4 cwt. The WEIGHTS of the Clock weigh nearly 2½ tons. WINDING is effected by electric motor, three times a week. There are 292 steps up to the clock room. “ BIG BEN,” the bell on which the clock strikes the hours, weighs 13 tons, and the hammer weighs 4 cwt. The 4 QUARTER BELLS weigh nearly 8 tons, viz. :— 3 tons 18 cwt., l ton 13 cwt., 1 ton 6 cwt. and l ton 1 cwt. respectively. THE CLOCK IS NOT AUTOMATICALLY SYNCHRO- NISED OR CONTROLLED but twice a day it telegraphs its time automatically to Greenwich Observatory, which enables its performance to be checked. Above the Clock are the Emblems of the Three Kingdoms and the Principality of Wales. The Chimes of “ Big Ben " are set to the following lines: “ ALL THROUGH .THIS HOUR, LORD, BE MY GUIDE, AND BY THY POWER, NO FOOT SHALL SLIDE.”

This is a divided back postcard with a 1904 postmark but I believe the image is earlier maybe 18991900 because the site on the corner of Parliament Street and Great George Street has been cleared in readiness for the building of the New Government Offices. There are several Police Officers dotted about the Square on Traffic points as well as Carriage Gates. The postcard is titled wrongly as 'The Victoria Tower', this is 'Big Ben' now named the 'Queen Elizabeth II Tower' since the Queen's Diamond Jubilee.

Another night shot, this time of Parliament Square taken from the west side of the square looking east. The statue in the foreground is of George Canning and it is in a garden area which was removed to make way for the widening of the square during the post WW2 remodel. The statue in the distance on the left is of the earl of Derby and on the right is Viscount Palmerston. All of these statues were moved to the west side of the remodelled square. The light on top of Big Ben is lit so the House of Commons was sitting at the time the photograph was taken. They rarely sit this late today.

This is the Teleprinter training classroom at Hendon circa 1981. The instructor had a reel to reel tape recorder in the classroom on which he played a continuous loop of 'Big Ben Banjo Band' music, if you could call it that. It used to drive the students batty. The instructor said however that if any student wanted to bring in their own favourite tunes, he would play them. Even in those days very few people had reel to reel recordings.
